title: The Israel-Gaza War: ‘Innocent Lives Being Lost on Both Sides’
description: Readers react to the ground invasion by Israel and a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Matthew Perry; shopping online and in person.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Panel Says That Innovative Sickle Cell Cure Is Safe Enough for Patients
description: The decision by an advisory committee may lead to Food and Drug Administration approval of the first treatment for humans that uses the CRISPR gene-editing system.
content: A panel of experts said on Tuesday that a groundbreaking treatment for sickle cell disease was safe enough for clinical use, setting the stage for likely federal approval by Dec. 8 of a powerful potential cure for an illness that afflicts more than 100,000 Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Robert De Niro Testifies at Trial Over Workplace Dispute: What to Know
description: A former employee accused Mr. De Niro of gender discrimination and retaliation; his company accused her of improper spending and abusing her work privileges.
content: A four-year legal battle between the actor Robert De Niro and a former employee went to trial on Monday in federal court in Manhattan, where competing claims of gender discrimination and improper spending were aired in open court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: Caster Semenya: ‘I’m Still a Woman’
description: In “The Race to Be Myself,” the Olympic runner tells the full story of her gender-based discrimination and dehumanization by the global athletics world.
content: In 2009, the 18-year-old South African track star Caster Semenya arrived in Berlin to run in the 800-meter event in that year’s World Championships. But before she was allowed to participate in the race — which she won — the International Association of Athletics Federations subjected her to multiple rounds of nonconsensual “gender confirmation tests” in response to public speculation that she was unfairly competing in the women’s category because of rumors she was male. A panel of German doctors tried to perform a transvaginal ultrasound on her, with only an English-German translator present (English is Semenya’s second language). She refused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life
description: Nine hundred feet up a rock, I began to question my parenting strategy.
content: When my wife and I took our 7-year-old son to climb a 900-hundred-foot piece of rock near our home in Colorado, it seemed like a good idea at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: King Charles, Visiting Kenya, Faces Calls to Answer for Colonial Abuses
description: Older Kenyans who lived through the British colonial period want an apology and reparations. Younger Kenyans want an acknowledgment of more recent alleged abuses by British companies and troops.
content: At 86, his gnarled hands grasping a walking stick as he ambled around his small patch of land facing Mount Kenya, Joseph Macharia Mwangi recalled with bitterness the years that he had spent fighting the British colonial government in Kenya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Autoworkers’ Victories
description: The pay increases are the largest that autoworkers have received in decades.
content: If you want to understand why the United Auto Workers union has evidently won its strikes against Detroit’s Big Three, it helps to return to the work of a 20th-century economist named Richard Lester.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: A Footpath in England, Torn Down, Keeps Being Rebuilt by ‘Fairies’
description: A small bridge in the English village of Stiffkey, northeast of Cambridge, was dismantled last year. It was rebuilt overnight, dismantled a second time and rebuilt again.
content: A small, beloved footbridge in the county of Norfolk has been dismantled twice only to be replaced by “local fairies,” according to village lore, in a long-running dispute between a coastal English village and the National Trust, a conservation charity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Man Accused in Fatal Beating of Sikh Driver Faces Hate Crimes Charges
description: The man who killed Jasmer Singh, 66, was motivated by “rage inflamed by hate,” the Queens district attorney said.
content: A man accused of beating a 66-year-old Sikh man to death after a minor car crash this month was motivated by “rage inflamed by hate,” the Queens district attorney said on Tuesday while announcing that the killing was now being prosecuted as a hate crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Should I Be Taking Supplements?
description: There are thousands on the market, but relatively few situations where they’re proven to be beneficial.
content: Q: Are any supplements proven to be helpful for health?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum and Jan Ransom
title: New York’s Embattled Jails Leader Gets a New Job in City Hall
description: Louis A. Molina had been head of the Correction Department since 2022 but failed to improve conditions at the perennially troubled jails.
content: New York City’s embattled jails commissioner will be moved to another position in Mayor Eric Adams’s administration after a tenure in which his failure to reverse the chaos and violence at the Rikers Island complex raised the possibility of a federal takeover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Wins Suit That Blamed Its Software for Deadly Crash
description: The decision by a California jury is the first involving a fatal accident that lawyers representing the victims said was the fault of Tesla’s self-driving technology.
content: A California jury ruled on Tuesday that a crash that killed a Tesla owner and seriously injured two passengers was not the fault of the carmaker’s driver-assistance software.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Courtney Bryan’s Music Brings It All Together
description: A recent recipient of the MacArthur “genius” grant, this pianist and composer fuses different styles for a sound that is entirely her own.
content: The name Courtney Bryan is not one that you’ll currently find on many recordings. Aside from two independently released, jazz-tilting albums from 2007 and 2010, precious little of this pianist and composer’s finely woven, adventurous music is available to hear widely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Weighs When Officials May Block Citizens on Social Media
description: The justices struggled to distinguish private conduct, which is not subject to the First Amendment, from state action, which is.
content: The Supreme Court worked hard in a pair of arguments on Tuesday to find a clear constitutional line separating elected officials’ purely private social media accounts from ones that reflect government actions and are subject to the First Amendment. After three hours, though, it was not clear that a majority of the justices had settled on a clear test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Wildfire in Southern California Forces Thousands From Their Homes
description: The Highland Fire, in a rural area southeast of Los Angeles, was 10 percent contained as of Tuesday evening.
content: A wildfire in a rural area southeast of Los Angeles had forced the evacuation of thousands of people and burned more than 2,400 acres as of Tuesday evening, local officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Biden Administration Approves Biggest Offshore Wind Farm Yet, in Virginia
description: The decision comes as other projects to build wind farms along the Atlantic Coast have run into trouble.
content: The Interior Department on Tuesday approved a plan to install up to 176 giant wind turbines off the coast of Virginia, clearing the way for what would be the nation’s largest offshore wind farm yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Why Doug Burgum Is Staying in a Race He Can Afford to Lose
description: With a substantial personal fortune, the North Dakota governor is insistent on spreading his message despite calls to drop out.
content: Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota knows that many people, including powerful voices in his own party, think he should quit the Republican presidential primary, abandoning his quixotic bid so that momentum can gather behind a challenger to Donald J. Trump, and ultimately President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Perlman
title: The Cost of Being Disabled in New York City Housing
description: Some landlords are asking disabled people to foot the bill for accommodations, leaving even those with ample resources without an accessible place to live.
content: As a wheelchair user, I have always had to pay a premium to live in an apartment independently. In my nine years living in New York City, I have spent more than $18,500 on automatic door openers, amenities just to make the places I’ve lived in accessible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Books Offer Shelter From the Storm of Dementia
description: Mixing the medical and the personal, several memoirists find literary analogies the best way to capture unwelcome visits to “unimaginable lands.”
content: “How did you go bankrupt?” one character asks another in Hemingway’s “The Sun Also Rises.” “Gradually and then suddenly,” comes the reply that has been latterly used to characterize crises from the coronavirus to climate change to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Israel advances on Gaza City.
content: The Israeli military advanced deeper into Gaza yesterday, approaching Gaza City from three directions. Israel has provided only limited details about the invasion, but photos and videos verified by The New York Times, as well as satellite imagery, showed troops and armored vehicles closing in on the city, Gaza’s largest, from the north, east and south. Israel has also continued to batter the territory with airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: Kenneth Branagh’s Short, Shallow ‘King Lear’
description: The veteran actor directs and plays the title role in a brisk and curiously weightless London production.
content: “Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks,” Lear famously lets rip in an open-air encounter with the elements that should strike at the heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller
title: Why Can’t We Give Up the Ghosting?
description: How a disappearing act became the default ending to so much human interaction.
content: Horror movies are always a good reflection of the culture that created them. In the 1980s, as if in response to the repressive evangelical movement gaining hold in American politics, grotesque body horror (“The Fly,” “Society”) became a defining genre, along with a succession of gratuitously violent slasher films in which hormonal teenagers meet gruesome ends, usually just beyond the sphere of adult supervision (“The Burning,” “Friday the 13th,” “Sleepaway Camp”). In the 1990s, horror films grew more excessive, with bigger budgets, but some added irony and self-awareness to speak to a generation of jaded young viewers who had seen it all: The potential victims in Wes Craven’s “Scream” (1996) display a deep knowledge of horror film tropes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Scary Movies
description: What was the first scary movie you saw?
content: What was your first, true afraid-to-do-anything-alone-afterward scary movie?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Strikes Densely Populated Area
description: Plus the power of music at a volatile time.
content: An Israeli strike aimed at Hamas militants, including a commander who helped plan the Oct. 7 massacre, hit a densely populated neighborhood in Gaza, leaving behind a massive crater and widespread damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Zverev Is Fined in New Abuse Case Involving Former Partner
description: The German tennis star was ordered to pay a penalty in a case involving the alleged physical abuse of the mother of his child, his lawyers said.
content: Alexander Zverev, the German tennis star who is accused of physically abusing the mother of his child, was ordered by a court in Berlin to pay a fine in the case, his lawyers said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: American Commandos Are in Israel Helping to Locate Hostages, Pentagon Says
description: A Defense Department official, Christopher P. Maier, declined to say how many U.S. Special Operations forces were currently in Israel. But other U.S. officials say the Defense Department has dispatched several dozen commandos in recent days.
content: American commandos on the ground in Israel are helping locate the more than 200 hostages seized during Hamas’s surprise cross-border attacks on Oct. 7, the Pentagon’s top special operations policy official said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Karen Zraick and Emma Bubola
title: A Deadly Airstrike, and Gazans at the Breaking Point
description: Israel said it killed a Hamas leader at a refugee camp, but many other people were wounded and killed, Hamas said. The assault came as fuel, food and water shortages pushed civilians to the brink.
content: An airstrike that Israel said was targeting Hamas militants caused widespread damage in a densely populated neighborhood of Gaza on Tuesday. Hamas and hospital officials said numerous people were killed and wounded, as humanitarian organizations warned that the territory’s civilian population was at a breaking point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: In this month’s picks, an actor and a director reflect on their careers, while another director reflects on everything else.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: America’s Rifle Fetish Is Destroying Its Sense of Freedom
description: Loving our guns to death.
content: In Anthony Mann’s 1950 western “Winchester ’73,” a rare and much-desired Winchester rifle brings misery and death to the unlucky souls who manage to bring it into their possession. In the West as brought to you by Mann — and his star, a troubled and morally ambiguous Jimmy Stewart — the gun isn’t a symbol of freedom as much as it is a curse, destined to ruin everyone who covets its power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: News Group Says A.I. Chatbots Heavily Rely on News Content
description: The News Media Alliance, a trade group that represents newspapers, says that A.I. chatbots use news articles significantly more than generic content online.
content: News publishers have argued for the past year that A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT rely on copyrighted articles to power the technology. Now the publishers say developers of these tools disproportionately use news content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Does Salvation for California’s Redwoods Lie Out of State?
description: A conversation with Moises Velasquez-Manoff about an effort to plant redwoods in the Pacific Northwest as threats mount to their habitat in California.
content: California has some impressive distinctions when it comes to trees: The state is home to the largest, tallest and oldest trees in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Saudi Arabia Confirmed as Sole Bidder for 2034 World Cup
description: Australia announced it would not bid, clearing the way for the Saudis to bring soccer’s biggest tournament back to the Gulf.
content: Saudi Arabia emerged as the likely winner in the abbreviated race to host soccer’s World Cup in 2034 on Tuesday after Australia’s soccer federation announced that it would not bid for the tournament. The decision removed what was the only potential hurdle in the way of Saudi Arabia’s plan to bring the world’s most-watched sporting event back to the Gulf.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Shied Away From Telling Him’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My husband is a bit of an introvert. Me? Not so much. Shortly after we moved from Brooklyn, N.Y. to Durham, N.C., a friend invited us to another person’s costume karaoke party. Knowing I really wanted to go dressed as members from the band Odyssey, my husband put on a wig, unbuttoned his shirt, wore my shell necklace and carried a blue guitar. Turns out my friend was wrong: It was not a costume party. Instead of fleeing or getting angry, my husband stayed in costume all night long, loudly wearing his love for me for all to see. — Pam Bash
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: School Cellphone Bans Are Trending. Do They Work?
description: Proponents say no-phone rules reduce student distractions and bullying. Critics say the bans could hinder student self-direction and critical thinking.
content: Earlier this year, Florida passed a law requiring public schools statewide to ban student cellphone use during class time. The new state rules reflect an intensifying global crackdown on young people and social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jameel Jaffer
title: What Matters Most in the Supreme Court’s Upcoming Social Media Cases
description: The justices should remember that the First Amendment’s highest purpose is to protect the speech that’s necessary to democracy.
content: Americans spend a lot of time on social media, and this term the Supreme Court will do the same. Over the next few months — beginning Tuesday — the court will hear a series of cases requiring it to resolve First Amendment questions arising out of the role that major social media platforms play in hosting, shaping and setting the limits of public discourse online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Poland’s Ruling Party Casts Doubt on Election That Cost It Power
description: Loyalists of Poland’s Law and Justice party are questioning the legitimacy of the election won this month by an alliance of opposition parties.
content: After eight years of pumping out vitriol against opponents of Poland’s governing party, state-controlled television has rallied to an unlikely new cause: a free media and fair play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: After Decades in the Restaurant Business, Andrew Carmellini Opens Café Carmellini
description: Marcus Samuelsson opens Metropolis in the new Perelman Performing Arts Center, Blue Ribbon adds a chop house spot to its lineup and more restaurant news.
content: The chef Andrew Carmellini’s trajectory has been a steady climb, not a rocketing blastoff. Now, having reached cruising altitude after 30 years at the stove in New York, a city where his family has roots, he’s finally putting his name on a restaurant. It’s in a first-class building, formerly a bank and now a hotel, designed by McKim, Mead & White and offering a spacious dining room at double height with an open kitchen on one side, a plethora of detailed finishes in wood, and mirrors and bronze throughout. It’s a gracious setting — “tablecloths are back,” he said. Wine-friendly, French-Italian dishes include Wagyu carpaccio; veal tongue Castelluccio (with lentils); crab and Meyer lemon salad; lobster cannelloni with caviar; sole Normande; black bass with truffle zabaglione; squab en croûte; and scallops Cardoz that pay homage to Floyd Cardoz, known for his interpretations of Indian food. Mr. Carmellini plans to spend most of his time at this new flagship working with his chef de cuisine, Kyle Goldstein. The pastry chef, Jeffrey Wurtz, has a diverse repertoire, including sticky toffee pudding, olive oil cake with Sorrento lemon, and passion fruit chiboust with coconut sorbet. The wine cellar, overseen by Josh Nadel from NoHo Hospitality Group, Mr. Carmellini’s company that’s also running the food and drink for the hotel, has some 1,800 labels. There will be three sommeliers on duty. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Hughes
title: The Joy of Picking Up Other People’s Trash
description: When my neighborhood changed around me, I decided to change it.
content: I’ve become a real kvetch. I have lived in the same neighborhood, in Brooklyn, for the better part of the past decade, spending the last five years in a hand-me-down apartment from a friend. One day I recognized where I lived; the next, I didn’t. Overnight, gaggles of 20-somethings began to roam the streets, presumably in search of eyebrows, which none of them seemed to have. Rent became obscene. I’d find myself the only Black person standing on the corner, waiting for the light to change. New high-rises as elegant as Lego blocks appeared on what seemed like every other street. Passive-aggressive notes from new residents started popping up in my lobby. One night, I came home to a can of alcoholic seltzer on top of my mailbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why It Was Worth $49,000 to Become Brooklyn Org
description: The Brooklyn Community Foundation has rebranded with a new name and a new web address.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. What’s in a name? We’ll find out about a Brooklyn nonprofit that rebranded itself after buying a model URL. We’ll also meet the cousins behind one of the state’s first licensed marijuana dispensaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: plaintive
description: This word has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word plaintive has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 29 in “Sinead O’Connor, Prince and the Thrill of ‘Nothing Compares 2 U’” by Christopher Kuo:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: This Florida School District Banned Cellphones. Here’s What Happened.
description: Schools in Orlando took a tougher approach than a new state law required. Student engagement increased. So did the hunt for contraband phones.
content: One afternoon last month, hundreds of students at Timber Creek High School in Orlando poured into the campus’s sprawling central courtyard to hang out and eat lunch. For members of an extremely online generation, their activities were decidedly analog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Home Sellers Win $1.8 Billion After Jury Finds Conspiracy Among Realtors
description: The influential National Association of Realtors and several brokerages were ordered to pay damages to home sellers who said they were forced to pay excessive fees to real estate agents.
content: A federal jury ruled on Tuesday that the powerful National Association of Realtors and several large brokerages had conspired to artificially inflate the commissions paid to real estate agents, a decision that could radically alter the home-buying process in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Where Israelis, Palestinians and Iranians Must Listen to One Another
description: Students from the Middle East come to Berlin to study music with the star conductor Daniel Barenboim. Now the Israel-Hamas war is testing their ideals.
content: The young musicians, in jeans and fuzzy sweaters, had just finished rehearsing a Prokofiev symphony in an empty concert hall. Then they put away their instruments and settled back into their orchestra chairs to talk about the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Eric Schmitt
title: Israel Faces Hostage Dilemma in Gaza
description: The country has said there are two main goals in the war: Destroy Hamas and free the hostages held in Gaza. But are those goals compatible?
content: As terrified families of hostages abducted by Hamas hold tense vigils, voicing fears that Israel’s ground attacks in Gaza could take the lives of their loved ones, the country got a rare bit of good news on Monday: Israeli soldiers had secretly rescued a 19-year-old woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Troops Battle Into Gaza as Airstrike Draws Conflicting Claims
description: Photographs taken on Tuesday showed a large crater and significant damage to buildings at the Jabaliya neighborhood in northern Gaza, the site of a densely populated refugee camp.
content: Israeli troops and tanks fought their way deeper into the northern Gaza Strip on Tuesday, according to Israeli and Gazan officials, who described battles with Hamas fighters and troop movements drawing closer to the territory’s main city and the warren of tunnels beneath it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Bids Adieu to Mike Pence’s Presidential Bid
description: Stephen Colbert said he was surprised to learn that the former vice president had been running for the White House. “It hadn’t registered,” he said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Is Buying Real Estate With a Friend Really a Good Idea?
description: For two art enthusiasts who went in together on a “cathedral-esque” country house outside New York City, it seemed brilliant: “Why wouldn’t we do this?”
content: In the early days of the pandemic, Jonathan Travis and his friend Ethan Rafii were visiting another friend’s country house outside New York City when they began to dream big. What if they pooled their resources and bought a shared house together?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Sara Curtis, Elyssa Dudley, Lynn Levy, Tina Antolini, Daniel Ramirez, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell and Rowan Niemisto
title: What Is the Scariest Song of All Time? Poem? YouTube Video?
description: Times writers revealed their picks. Listen at your own risk.
content: For Halloween, we asked writers and editors around The New York Times for the pieces of art or culture that they turn to when they need a good scare. The result is a collection of audio stories that will send a chill down your spine, make your hair stand on end and keep you entertained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth G. Dunn
title: The Apple-Picking Apocalypse of Upstate New York
description: Eight straight weekends of rain have pushed the pick-your-own orchards toward financial disaster.
content: It was a beautiful Friday afternoon in the Hudson Valley, 70 degrees in October and not a cloud in the sky: perfect weather for apple picking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Milton Esterow and Tracy Sherlock
title: The Busy Doctor Who Gave Himself Another Job: Tracking Nazi Loot
description: Despite limited success, Dr. Michael R. Hayden has spent more than a decade patiently searching for the looted silver Judaica stolen from his grandparents, who were killed by the Nazis.
content: His day began at 6 a.m. with a call to Amsterdam from his office in Vancouver. An hour later he gave an online lecture to a class in Ireland, immediately followed by a call with a scientist in Boston about research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno, Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Denies Knowing FTX Money Was Missing, as He Concludes Testimony
description: The founder of the FTX crypto exchange was grilled by a federal prosecutor for a second day, just before both sides rested their case in the criminal fraud trial.
content: Over and over on Tuesday, Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange, denied knowing that billions of dollars in customer money had been misappropriated until shortly before his company collapsed last year, as a federal prosecutor grilled him for a second day in his criminal fraud trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Zack Beauchamp
description: The Oct. 31, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Zack Beauchamp. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Now Showing, an Ancient Spell Book for the Dead
description: An exhibition at the Getty reveals the Egyptian Book of the Dead, long relegated to a dark vault, in the light of day.
content: In the mid-19th century, a British antiquarian named Sir Thomas Phillipps announced his intention of owning one copy of every book in the world. A professed “vello-maniac,” Mr. Phillipps, a quarrelsome baronet, bought manuscripts indiscriminately from booksellers with whom he engaged in ceaseless battle. Soon there was hardly room in his moldering Cotswolds mansion for his second wife, Elizabeth, who eventually moved to a boardinghouse in Torquay, an English working-class seaside resort. By the time Mr. Phillipps died in 1872, he had amassed an unparalleled collection of 60,000 documents and 50,000 printed books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: New Zealand Volcano Owner Is Found Guilty of Safety Failure
description: The ruling brings an end to legal proceedings that began after the White Island eruption killed 22 people in 2019.
content: Nearly four years after 22 people were killed by a volcanic eruption on White Island in New Zealand, a court ruled that the company that owns the island was guilty of violating a safety law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim and Saeed Al-Batati
title: Yemen’s Houthi militia claims to have launched an attack on Israel.
description: The Israeli military said it had thwarted a batch of “aerial threats” but did not say who was behind them.
content: Yemen’s Houthi militia claimed an attempted attack on southern Israel on Tuesday, saying it had launched a “large batch” of ballistic and cruise missiles as well as drones toward Israeli targets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Barbieri and Joe Rennison
title: Japan Takes Another Step Away From Easy Money
description: The Bank of Japan said it would be more flexible in how it managed government bond yields, citing rising inflation.
content: The people who work the levers of Japan’s economy are in a bind: The country’s low interest rates, which they have long used to goose growth, are now well out of step with other big economies. Bridging that gap is tricky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Detains Two Soldiers Suspected of Killing 9 Civilians
description: The arrest in an occupied area of Ukraine was a rare admission by Moscow that its forces may have committed a crime against Ukrainian civilians. Experts warned that it might just be political posturing.
content: Two Russian soldiers have been detained in connection with the killing of nine people, including two children, in Ukrainian territory controlled by Moscow, Russian authorities said, in a rare admission that occupying forces may have committed a crime against Ukrainian civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Ian Stewart, Allison Benedikt, Jessica Metzger and Dan Powell
title: Israel’s Hostage Dilemma
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
content: The Israeli military said today that 240 people were taken hostage during the Hamas attack on Oct. 7. As Israeli forces move closer to Gaza City, families continue to demand that the government prioritize the safety and rescue of their loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Beukes
title: The Man Who Was Always Hungry
description: A.K. Blakemore’s novel “The Glutton” reimagines the life of an 18th-century sideshow performer who could eat almost anything.
content: You can’t trust poets. They feel too keenly for other people, are too ready to climb into the hearts and guts of things and lay them bare and bloody and obscenely beautiful in front of you. Even monsters. Maybe especially monsters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Fruit Purée Pouches May Contain Lead, F.D.A. Warns Parents
description: Children who have had WanaBana apple cinnamon fruit purée pouches should get a blood test, federal officials said. An investigation found that the purée had “extremely high concentrations of lead.”
content: Federal health officials are warning parents and caregivers not to buy WanaBana apple cinnamon fruit purée pouches or feed them to their children because the product may contain elevated levels of lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: F.B.I. Says Israel-Hamas War Raises Potential for Attack Against Americans
description: Since the attacks by Hamas, antisemitic threats in the U.S. have reached “historic levels,” the agency’s director said. Threats against Muslims have also increased.
content: The F.B.I. director warned Tuesday that the Israel-Hamas war had raised the potential for an attack against Americans to a new level and escalated threats against Jews and Muslims in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: It’s All About the Grid
description: Billions of dollars in new U.S. funding won’t be enough
content: Last April, I traveled to Maine to report on a stalled effort to bring clean hydropower from Canada to New England. Mistrustful residents had sued to block the 145-mile transmission line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Key Measure of Wages Grew at a Moderate Pace This Summer
description: The Employment Cost Index, which Federal Reserve officials watch closely as a gauge of pay trends, has come down since last year.
content: A measure of pay and benefits that officials at the Federal Reserve have been watching closely as they try to gauge the heat of the labor market grew at a moderate pace over the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: In Chicago, a Neighborhood of Immigrants Is Conflicted About More Arrivals
description: Brighton Park has taken in immigrants for generations, but residents are split over plans to house migrants in winterized tents on an empty lot.
content: For generations, Chicago’s Brighton Park neighborhood has been made and remade by successive waves of immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: Matthew Perry and the Loneliness of Addiction
description: He was a brilliant performer, but his honesty will be his greatest legacy.
content: A long time ago, I lay awake for hours, terrified that they would be my last ones on earth. I had committed myself to quitting cocaine, which was my second addiction, the first being years of amphetamines. I was devoting myself to cleaning up and getting healthy. But then a friend called who I had routinely done coke with and who always had a supply of the drug. Earlier on that black night, I’d careened backward into the familiar land of white lines on a mirror and a heart racing way too fast. It was pounding so hard, so fast, so loud, I was certain it and I couldn’t survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man Indicted Over Threats to D.A. and Sheriff in Trump’s Georgia Case
description: “Be looking over your shoulder,” the man said in a voice mail message for Fani Willis, the Fulton County prosecutor who filed charges against former President Donald Trump.
content: A man who threatened a prosecutor and a sheriff involved in the Georgia investigation of former President Donald J. Trump for election interference was indicted in federal court on Monday, the U.S. Attorney’s Office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Gov. Hochul Announces $75 Million to Combat Hate Crimes in New York
description: The governor announced grants for houses of worship and local police departments following an uptick in attacks.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced on Tuesday up to $75 million in grants for local police departments and houses of worship in response to an uptick in reported antisemitic attacks and hate crimes against Palestinians in the wake of the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and William K. Rashbaum
title: Bankman-Fried’s Risky Defense Strategy Faces Another Big Test
description: The fallen crypto mogul’s decision to take the stand was long seen as a gamble. That risk will come into focus again on Tuesday as his testimony continues.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried is to return to the stand today after the former wunderkind faced a four-hour grilling that exposed inconsistencies in his assertion that he didn’t defraud customers of FTX, his bankrupt crypto exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Ouyang
title: Bariatric Surgery at 16
description: If childhood obesity is an ‘epidemic,’ how far should doctors go to treat it?
content: Last fall, Alexandra Duarte, who is now 16, went to see her endocrinologist at Texas Children’s Hospital, outside Houston. From age 10, she had been living with polycystic ovary syndrome and, more recently, prediabetes. After Alexandra described her recent quinceañera, the doctor brought up an operation that might benefit her, one that might help her lose weight and, as a result, improve these obesity-related problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Karen Zraick
title: Photos show an explosion has caused heavy damage in Gaza’s Jabaliya neighborhood.
description: Photographs taken on Tuesday showed at least one large crater and significant damage to buildings at the Jabaliya neighborhood in northern Gaza, home of a long-established refugee camp.
content: Photographs taken on Tuesday showed at least one large crater and significant damage to buildings at the Jabaliya neighborhood in northern Gaza, home of a long-established refugee camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: If Not This, Then What Should Israel Do?
description: Zack Beauchamp analyzes Israel’s response to the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: “Two things are true: Israel must do something, and what it’s doing now is indefensible.” So writes Zack Beauchamp, a senior correspondent at Vox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rozina Ali
title: American Muslims Are in a Painful, Familiar Place
description: There seems to be a sense of both resignation (we’ve been here before) and shock (but we’ve been here before).
content: When President Biden landed in Tel Aviv days after Hamas’s Oct. 7 massacre of more than 1,400 people, he told an audience of Israelis that this was not just Israel’s Sept. 11, that “it was like 15 9/11s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: With Executive Order, White House Tries to Balance A.I.’s Potential and Peril
description: President Biden announced regulations on Monday that seemed to have a little bit for everyone.
content: How do you regulate something that has the potential to both help and harm people, that touches every sector of the economy and that is changing so quickly even the experts can’t keep up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu and Elliott Jerome Brown Jr
title: The Met Opera Puts On a Malcolm X Marathon
description: Ahead of its new production of Anthony Davis’s “X,” the house hosted a starry, 18-hour reading of Malcolm X’s autobiography.
content: For 18 hours on a rainy Sunday this Halloween weekend, the Metropolitan Opera House was visited by the ghost of Malcolm X.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Second Maryland Man to Receive an Altered Pig’s Heart Has Died
description: Researchers said they found signs of organ rejection, which the genetically modified tissue was supposed to prevent.
content: A 58-year-old man with heart failure who received a new heart from a genetically modified pig died on Monday, nearly six weeks after receiving the pig organ, University of Maryland Medical Center officials announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: In Global Race to Offer Green Subsidies, U.K. Prefers Slow and Steady
description: Competing against sizable U.S. incentives, Britain is choosing a less expensive route, winning some fans while exasperating others.
content: The question of how Britain will respond to President Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act, the $369 billion landmark legislation offering deep subsidies for green investment, has followed Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s finance minister, for most of the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Karoun Demirjian
title: Johnson’s Israel Aid Bill Sets Stage for a Clash Over Security Assistance
description: By splitting money for Israel’s war effort from aid to Ukraine and coupling it with spending cuts, Speaker Mike Johnson has put the House on a collision course with the Senate and President Biden.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson’s decision to force a stand-alone vote on aid for Israel, peeling off a request from the Biden administration for money from Ukraine and coupling it with spending cuts, has set up a confrontation between the House and Senate over how to fund U.S. allies during the conflicts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: U.A.W. Strike Gains Could Reverberate Far Beyond Autos
description: Experts said the union’s new contracts could set precedents that give labor advantages when bargaining contracts and organizing workers.
content: Laying out a tentative contract agreement to end a six-week wave of walkouts at Ford Motor, the United Automobile Workers president made an unusual pitch to other labor unions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Warning Signs
description: Treat yourself to Kathy Lowden and Erik Piepenburg’s terrifyingly fun collaboration debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senate Confirms Lew as U.S. Ambassador to Israel
description: The vote reflected deep partisan divisions over Jacob Lew’s nomination, which nearly all Senate Republicans voted against.
content: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Jacob J. Lew as the next U.S. ambassador to Israel, filling a post that the Biden administration has argued is critical to efforts to help the country as it seeks to topple Hamas in the Gaza Strip and ward off additional challenges from other Iran-linked groups in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: The Hot New Thing in Social Media Is Here. Again.
description: Lapse, a new photo app, has entered the fray. Can it last?
content: The history of social media platforms is littered with apps that had their moment before fading. BeReal, the 2022 darling that required users to post just once a day at a random time, has lost momentum, according to Gen Z. Dispo, a photo-sharing platform inspired by disposable cameras, briefly made headlines in 2021. And in 2015 there was Beme, which was marketed as an online space for sharing everyday life as it really is.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 31, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about the 25th anniversary of the album “The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill” misstated one of the guests onstage with the Fugees at the Prudential Center. Rah Digga joined the group, not Remy Ma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: The Many People Behind ‘The Woman in Me’
description: Three authors helped Britney Spears get her life story on the page.
content: “If you follow me on Instagram, you thought this book was going to be written in emojis, didn’t you?” Britney Spears asks at the end of her memoir, “The Woman in Me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: A Meteoric Career, Cut Short, Still Burns Bright
description: Michael Richards, who died on 9/11, expanded the political possibilities of art. His sculptures embodied suffering and hope in a way that now seems prescient.
content: A heavy irony hangs over Michael Richards’s work: The artist known for images of pilots, airplanes, wings and targets died, age 38, in the Sept. 11 attacks. He had spent the night in his studio on the 92nd floor of the World Trade Center’s north tower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What to Watch for as the Federal Reserve Meets This Week
description: Central bankers are expected to leave interest rates steady at a 22-year high of 5.25 to 5.5 percent. Investors are looking for hints at what’s next.
content: Federal Reserve officials are widely expected to leave interest rates steady at the conclusion of their two-day meeting on Wednesday. But investors and economists will watch for any hint about whether rates are likely to stay that way — or whether central bankers still think they might need to increase them again in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘I Can Get It for You Wholesale’ Review: Rag Trade Revival, Recut for Today
description: A story considered too dark for Broadway in its time is too much of a patchwork in ours.
content: What a shame that the 1962 musical “I Can Get It for You Wholesale,” a critique of vulture capitalism disguised as a rag trade comedy, is now best known as the Broadway show that gave Barbra Streisand her start at 19. No matter how good she was — and the recording of her big number, “Miss Marmelstein,” overflows with stupendous, youthful invention — hers was only a small, comic role in a much darker story by the novelist Jerome Weidman; her song a bauble in a fascinating and multifaceted score by Harold Rome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jenna Russell
title: After Mass Shooting in Maine, No Clarity on Whether Gun Laws Will Change
description: A state ban on assault weapons? Expanded concealed-carry restrictions? Tighter mental health laws? As Maine grieves, it weighs a roiling debate over gun laws.
content: On Sunday, Arthur Barnard will bury his oldest child, Artie Strout, 42, who was one of the 18 people killed in the country’s deadliest mass shooting so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: After 8-Hour Standoff Near Tokyo, Hostages Are Free and Suspect Is Held
description: The suspect, said by the Japanese media to be 86, was held after the police stormed a post office once two employees had reached safety.
content: The police in Japan arrested a suspect on Tuesday night after an armed man holed up in a post office in a Tokyo suburb and took two hostages, prompting a nearly eight-hour standoff that was an unsettling episode for a country where gun violence is extremely rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Let’s Make Some Meatballs
description: With plenty of tomato sauce, slabs of garlic bread and a big green salad — that’s dinner.
content: Everyone has comfort food. Here’s mine: juicy meatballs done Italian American style, served with homemade tomato sauce or piled on top of a spaghetti heap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Diana Nguyen, Luke Vander Ploeg, Olivia Natt, Shannon Lin, John Ketchum, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: A Historic Strike (and Win) for Autoworkers
description: The tentative deals with Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades.
content: A wave of strikes that has paralyzed the auto industry came to an end on Monday, when the last of the three big car manufacturers, General Motors, reached a deal with the United Automobile Workers union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Rancorous Primary Fight Brews Over Democrat’s Stance on Israel
description: Representative Jamaal Bowman’s calls for Israel to stand down on Gaza may fuel a perilous primary challenge for one of the left’s brightest stars.
content: Representative Jamaal Bowman was already facing blowback from Jewish leaders in his district and a growing primary threat for bucking his party’s stance on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Maggie Astor
title: Trump Sues to Ensure He Is on the Ballot in Michigan
description: Donald Trump’s lawsuit was the latest turn in a nationwide battle over his eligibility to hold office again, including a case being heard this week in Colorado.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump sued Michigan’s top elections official, seeking to ensure he would be on the ballot for the 2024 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Prosecutors End Flint Water Crisis Case Against Ex-Governor
description: Michigan prosecutors had charged former Gov. Rick Snyder with neglect of duty, but said appellate court rulings left them unable to pursue the case against him and 8 others.
content: Prosecutors in Michigan said Tuesday that a series of appellate court rulings meant they could no longer pursue criminal cases against the state’s former governor, Rick Snyder, and others accused of wrongdoing in the Flint water crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Venezuela Tries to Squash Opposition Campaign Before It Even Starts
description: The government’s move to annul the election of a candidate to challenge President Nicolás Maduro raises questions about its commitment to a free election.
content: It seemed like a small glimmer of hope for supporters of democracy, after years of authoritarian rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Military-Industrial-Complex Complex
description: National security isn’t a monetary issue.
content: Like most people who opine about politics and policy, I routinely talk in terms of left versus right. But when I do, I sometimes encounter people who decry this approach as simplistic. Surely, they argue, people are more complicated than that, and don’t have views that can be neatly summarized by a single dimension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Looks to Allay European Fears of a Subsidy War
description: Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, argued in a speech in Germany that the Biden administration’s climate law is not protectionist.
content: The Biden administration is trying to ease European concerns about America’s new climate and tax law, which some allies view as a protectionist industrial policy that threatens their economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis, Christoph Koettl and Bora Erden
title: Videos show a densely populated area of Gaza decimated by Israel’s airstrike.
description: The Times analyzed satellite imagery and social media posts of the aftermath.
content: A Times analysis of satellite imagery and social media videos shows that an airstrike Israel said targeted a senior leader of Hamas on Tuesday had destroyed a densely populated area in the Jabaliya neighborhood, which is home to the largest refugee camp in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Struck a Dense Area in Gaza, Saying It Killed Hamas Militants
description: Also, the new speaker sets up a clash over military aid. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Airstrikes that Israel said were aimed at Hamas militants hit the densely populated area of Jabaliya in Gaza today, leaving a large crater and causing widespread damage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Candy That Grew From Kernel to Icon
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 31, 2023.
content: “It is the ultimate survival sugar rush. Candy corn don’t go bad. It’ll last forever.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Europe’s Economy Falters, Diverging From Strong Growth in U.S.
description: Economic growth in the eurozone contracted 0.1 percent last quarter, and inflation in October fell to a two-year low, a sign that high interest rates were taking a toll.
content: As the United States economy powers ahead, Europe is moving along a very different path: a drawn-out economic slowdown burdened by a double dose of high interest rates and the lingering impact of Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Dancing Nun Is the Stuff of Horror in Mexico
description: “La Monja de la Feria,” a scary nun character, has delighted and unsettled millions with popular videos that showcase her dance moves atop a fair ride. But why is this peculiar scene so popular?
content: The nefarious nun stood at the center of an amusement ride at the national fair in Durango, Mexico, her black veil draped, her demonic teeth gnarled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Aaron Krolik and Paul Mozur
title: In Cyberattacks, Iran Shows Signs of Improved Hacking Capabilities
description: A monthslong hacking campaign targeted the governments of regional rivals, including Israel, and marked a turn, a new report says, as the attacks were used to collect intelligence, not just disrupt services.
content: Iranian hackers are waging a sophisticated espionage campaign targeting the country’s rivals across the Middle East and attacking key defense and intelligence agencies, according to a leading Israeli-American cybersecurity company, a sign of how Iran’s quickly improving cyberattacks have become a new, important prong in a shadow war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: How Posters of Kidnapped Israelis Ignited a Firestorm on American Sidewalks
description: In the weeks since Hamas attacked Israel, fliers depicting the hostages have become ubiquitous. But in cities and on college campuses across the globe, anti-Israel protesters have removed them.
content: “KIDNAPPED,” the posters say, in big block letters above pictures of people taken hostage by Hamas terrorists during the Oct. 7 attack in Israel, urgent reminders of the men, women and children still being held hostage in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose and Phoebe Lett
title: Why Modern Micromanagement of Kids Is Spooky
description: For Halloween, try this parenting hack: Back off.
content: The Halloween season means one thing for today’s parents: work. There’s costumes, there’s decorations and, if you follow parenting trends, there’s now convincing your kids to hand over their candy to the “switch witch.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Introduction to the Mountain Goats
description: How do you start listening to a band with 22 albums? We’re here to help.
content: When an artist you’re curious about but unfamiliar with has an extensive back catalog, it can be difficult to know where to start. Sometimes a trusted guide is needed. And when people learn I’m a fan of the Mountain Goats — the wildly prolific, verbose and cult-beloved group led by the singer-songwriter-novelist John Darnielle — I am sometimes called upon to be that guide. I’ve made multiple “introduction to the Mountain Goats” mixes and playlists for friends over the years, and today I’ve made one for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Ready to Retire? Consider Your Family First.
description: Some older adults are skipping a sun-drenched post-work life and moving instead to the next step: choosing to live near children and grandchildren.
content: After touring several retirement communities, Marta Genoni winnowed the field to two appealing possibilities not far from the home she shared with her husband, Kenneth, a lawyer, in Westfield, N.J. But unable to make a final decision she asked her elder daughter, a college administrator in Richmond, Va., to come north and weigh in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Igoe
title: For One Writer, Crime Is a ‘Window’ Into Society
description: Sarah Weinman, who writes a monthly crime and mystery column for the Book Review, discussed her niche.
content: A murder in a Northern California coastal town. The unsolved case of a girl who disappeared near Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1956. A spray-painted message near a body, warning: “MIND YOUR BUSINESS.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Ben Hubbard
title: Hezbollah Hesitates as Israel Strikes Gaza
description: After years of spoiling for a fight with Israel, the group is torn between maintaining its credibility as a defender of the Palestinians, and its hesitation to drag Lebanon into a full-scale war.
content: As Israeli troops move deeper south into Gaza with the goal of destroying Hamas, the world is closely watching what happens on Israel’s northern border, where its forces have engaged for weeks in intense clashes with another, more powerful foe, Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Past Lies About War in the Middle East are Getting in the Way of the Truth Today
description: Many cannot forget the false or exaggerated claims that led to the Iraq war.
content: Moshe Lavi, whose relatives have been taken hostage by Hamas, recently talked to a group of New York Times journalists about his family’s agony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Aaron Spears, Drummer for Usher and Other Stars, Dies at 47
description: He received a Grammy nomination for Usher’s 2004 album “Confessions” and played on tracks by Ariana Grande, Lady Gaga and many other major pop musicians.
content: Aaron Spears, a Grammy-nominated drummer who played with Usher, Ariana Grande and many other major pop stars, has died. He was 47.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: A Handful of Luscious, Soapy, Sexy Romance Novels
description: Our romance columnist recommends four new books.
content: Regina Black’s THE ART OF SCANDAL (Grand Central, 292 pp., $28) is a gorgeously soapy debut where a mayor’s wife takes up with a young artist as her marriage goes down in flames. Rachel Abbott’s learns her spouse is cheating during his 40th birthday party, when he texts her a saucy picture clearly meant for someone else. An upcoming Senate run means it’s poor timing for a messy divorce. Rachel’s price is high: “One million dollars,” she tells him. “And the house. I won’t say anything about your affair or file for divorce until the election's over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel’s U.N. Ambassador Criticized for Wearing a Yellow Star of David
description: Dani Dayan, chairman of Yad Vashem museum in Jerusalem, said Israelis should instead display the country’s flag as a sign of strength.
content: The head of Israel’s Holocaust memorial on Tuesday criticized the country’s ambassador to the U.N. for wearing a yellow Star of David patch during an address to the Security Council, saying the symbol, which was used under the Nazis to identify Jews, dishonors both the country and victims of the Holocaust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: The Big Cheese (Tour)
description: A writer spends eight days exploring the world of British farmhouse cheeses, from London to the West Country, where a good Cheddar rules the day.
content: On a sunny October afternoon in the London neighborhood of Bermondsey, a cool breeze surprised me with the winy smell of apples. It brought on a sudden sharp craving for a nice chunk of Cheddar, the fruit and the cheese together being a favorite after-school snack when I was growing up in Connecticut. This was an appropriate prompt, too, since I was on my way to a very privileged lesson in British farmhouse cheeses at the beginning of an eight-day, cheese-themed trip to London and Somerset run by the specialty tour company Cheese Journeys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The First of Our Friends to Go
description: What do we mourn when we mourn a TV companion?
content: If you’re fortunate to live long enough, eventually you get The Call. Sometimes it’s an actual call, sometimes a social media post or a conversation on the street. But the message is the same: A friend of your youth has died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Bertie Bowman, Record-Setting Staff Member on Capitol Hill, Dies at 92
description: He was the longest-serving Black staff member in the history of the U.S. Congress, rising to a senior role with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
content: Bertie Bowman, who began his career sweeping the steps of the U.S. Capitol in 1944, joined the staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in 1965 and retired 56 years later, making him the longest-serving Black staff member in Congress, died on Wednesday in North Bethesda, Md. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Artificial Flavors’ Review: Blame ChatGPT for This Musical
description: Each performance culminates in a production, composed on the spot, with misguided help from artificial intelligence.
content: Artificial intelligence can paint meddlesome monkeys, speak in the basso profundo of James Earl Jones and play a tune to suit a hall of mirrors. But it can’t write a musical that doesn’t feel canned (at least, not yet). That’s the argument put forward by “Artificial Flavors,” a live demonstration of A.I.’s creative capabilities — and tedious limitations — at 59E59 Theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Suderman
title: On This Issue, Matt Gaetz Actually Has a Good Point
description: Why Speaker Johnson should bring back regular order.
content: Just days before winning the race for speaker of the House last week, Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana sent a letter to colleagues laying out a plan to complete the budget process by bringing 12 individual appropriations bills to the floor. Mr. Johnson billed his plan as a way to “allow us to demonstrate good governance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Flashback TV Quiz: The One About Chandler
description: Can you place 8 of these memorable “Friends” moments in order?
content: Can you place 8 of these memorable “Friends” moments in order?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: 6 Great Space Images in October
description: An eclipse's shadow from space, India's astronaut capsule and a confused space telescope.
content: An eclipse's shadow from space, India's astronaut capsule and a confused space telescope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Katherine Schulten
title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Gaza Strip, Matthew Perry, World Series
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Bought a House Together (and Haven’t Lived to Regret It)
description: For two art enthusiasts who pooled their resources to buy a country house outside New York City, the idea seemed brilliant: “Why wouldn’t we do this?”
content: For two art enthusiasts who pooled their resources to buy a country house outside New York City, the idea seemed brilliant: “Why wouldn’t we do this?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arijeta Lajka
title: Deadly Israeli Airstrike Hits Dense Area in Northern Gaza
description: The Israeli military said it was targeting a senior Hamas commander. Hamas and hospital officials said many people were killed.
content: The Israeli military said it was targeting a senior Hamas commander. Hamas and hospital officials said many people were killed.
source.name: The New York Times
